sentences.sentence: The man who had spoken to us climbed up to the driver’s seat, while we took our places inside.
We had hardly done so before the driver whipped( 鞭打 ) up his horse, and we set off at a furious( 高速的 ) pace through the foggy streets.
Miss Morstan was as resolute( 坚定的 ) and collected as ever.
I tried to amuse her with stories of my adventures in Afghanistan; but, to tell the truth, I was myself so excited and so curious that my stories were somewhat strange.
To this day she claims that I told her how a rifle( 来复枪 ) looked into my tent at the dead of night, and how I fired a tiger at it.
At first I had some idea as to the direction in which we were driving;
but soon, what with( 因为 ) our pace, the fog, and my own limited knowledge of London, I lost my sense of direction, and knew only that we seemed to be going a very long way.
Sherlock Holmes was never lost, however, and he muttered( 轻声低语 ) the street names as the cab hurried through the narrow, winding streets.
We had a brief view of the Thames with the lamps shining upon the broad, silent water; but our cab dashed on, and was soon in a maze( 迷宫似的街道 ) of streets upon the other side.
“Wordsworth Road,” said my companion. “Robert Street. Cold Harbor Lane( 路 ). Our quest( 探险 ) does not appear to take us to very fashionable( 有钱人常光顾的 ) regions( 区域 ).”
We, indeed, reached a questionable and forbidding neighborhood. Long lines of dull brick houses were only broken by tawdry( 俗气的 ) brilliance of corner pubs.
Then came rows of small two-storied houses, each with a small front garden,
and then unending lines of ugly new brick buildings—the monster( 怪物 ) tentacles which the giant( 巨大的 ) city was throwing out into the country.
At last the cab stopped at the third house in a new row.
None of the other houses were inhabited( 有人居住的 ), and the one where we stopped was as dark as its neighbors, except for a single glimmer( 微光 ) in the kitchen window.
On our knocking, however, the door was instantly thrown open( 打开 ) by an Indian servant wearing a yellow turban( 包头巾 ) and white loose-fitting clothes.
There was something out of place( 不协调 ) about this Oriental figure framed( 给（画等）装框 ) in the doorway of an ordinary suburban( 郊区的 ) house.
“The Sahib awaits( 等候 ) you,” said he, and even as he spoke there came a high voice from some inner( 内部的 ) room.
“Show them straight in to me,” it cried.
We followed the Indian down a plain and dirty corridor( 走廊 ), badly lit and worse furnished, until he came to a door upon the right, which he threw open( 打开 ).
A blaze( 光 ) of yellow light streamed out upon us, and in the center of it stood a small man with a very high bald( 光秃的 ) head and a little red hair round the edge of it.
Nature had given him a too visible( 明显的 ) line of yellow and irregular teeth, which he tried feebly( 无力地 ) to hide by constantly passing his hand over the lower part of his face.
In spite of( 尽管 ) his baldness, he seemed young.
In fact, he had just passed thirty.
We were all astonished by the appearance of the room into which he invited us.
In that dismal( 阴沉的 ) house, it looked as out of place as a perfect diamond in a setting of brass( 黄铜 ).
The richest of curtains and tapestries( 挂毯 ) covered the walls, with expensive-looking paintings and Oriental vases.
The carpet was so soft and so thick that the foot sank pleasantly into it, as into a bed of moss( 苔藓 ).
The two great tiger-skins on the floor, and the sweet smell of incense( 香 ) that filled the air, added to the atmosphere of Eastern luxury( 奢华 ).
“Please step into my little retreat( 隐居处 ). A small place, but furnished to my own liking.
An oasis( 绿洲 ) of art in the howling desert of South London. That painting over there, for instance, is a genuine( 真的 ) Corot...”
“You will excuse me( 请原谅 ), Mr. Sholto,” said Miss Morstan, “but I am here, at your request( 依照你的要求 ), to learn something which you desire to tell me.
It is very late, and I would like the interview to be as short as possible.”
“It has to take some time,” he answered, “for we shall certainly have to go to Norwood and see my brother Bartholomew, and see if we can persuade him.
He is very angry with me for taking the course which has seemed right to me.
You cannot imagine what a terrible fellow he is when he is angry.”
“If we are to go to Norwood it would perhaps be as well to start at once,” I ventured( 小心地说 ) to remark.
He laughed until his ears were quite red.
“That would hardly do,” he cried. “No, I must prepare you by showing you how we all stand in relation to( 牵涉到 ) each other.”
“My father was, as you may have guessed, Major John Sholto, once of the Indian army.
He retired some eleven years ago, and came to live at Pondicherry Lodge in Upper Norwood.
He brought back with him a considerable sum of money, a large collection of valuable antiques, and a staff of native servants.
With these advantages he bought himself a house, and lived in great luxury( 奢侈 ).
My twin brother Bartholomew and I were the only children.
I very well remember the sensation( 轰动 ) which was caused by the disappearance of Captain Morstan.
We read the details( 详情 ) in the papers, and, knowing that he had been a friend of our father’s, we discussed the case freely in his presence( 在他面前 ).
He used to join in our discussions as to what could have happened.
Never for an instant did we suspect( 怀疑 ) that he, and he alone, knew the fate( 命运 ) of Arthur Morstan.
We did know, however, that some danger overhung( 逼近 ) our father.
He was very fearful of going out alone, and he always employed two prize-fighters to act as guards at Pondicherry Lodge.
Williams, who drove you tonight, was one of them. He was once the boxing champion of England.
Our father would never tell us what he feared, but he had a very strong dislike of men with wooden legs.
On one occasion he actually fired his gun at a wooden-legged man, who proved to be a harmless tradesman.
We had to pay a large sum to keep it quiet.
My brother and I used to think this a mere whim( 冲动 ) of my father’s, but events have since led us to change our opinion.”
